since_last_update: Dominant cross-asset shock shifted toward “policy/regime + rates repricing”: Trump’s move to nominate Kevin Warsh as next Fed chair drove a stronger USD / higher yields impulse and a sharp reversal in precious metals (FT, Barron’s).

Precious-metals deleveraging risk became more immediate: gold and silver saw an outsized downside move tied to USD strength and Fed-chair narrative, raising the probability of VAR/margin-driven spillovers into broader risk (Barron’s).

Macro growth tone weakened from Asia: China’s official Manufacturing PMI fell back into contraction (49.3) and non-manufacturing also dipped below 50, reinforcing global growth-scare channels (Reuters).

Political risk premium widened into the weekend: a partial U.S. government shutdown began Jan 31 with DHS funding dispute unresolved; next step is a House vote expected Monday, adding headline/market-function risk (Guardian).

Geopolitical tail risk increased: Trump comments on sending ships to Iran reintroduce an escalation pathway that can flip correlations (risk-off + crude up + duration bid), even if follow-through is uncertain (Guardian).

Fed-speak skewed hawkish vs near-term cuts: Musalem framing policy as neutral / cuts not warranted pushes against easing expectations and is consistent with the broader USD/real-yield impulse (driver consistent with Warsh/rates narrative; source attribution for Warsh/rates impulse: FT).
today_focus: Primary driver check: “Fed regime uncertainty + rates repricing” remains the most plausible dominant tape driver, with USD strength / yield sensitivity hitting NQ-style duration and pressuring gold (FT, Barron’s).

Secondary driver: “government shutdown optics + data-flow risk” (potential delays/disruptions to economic releases and elevated weekend headline risk) rather than immediate macro fundamentals (Guardian).
Asia-to-US handoff: China PMI miss is the cleanest fresh macro datapoint and can keep cyclicals/commodities and global-growth sentiment heavy into Monday (Reuters).

Cross-asset stability watch: after the metals air-pocket, the key question is whether deleveraging stays contained (idiosyncratic to metals) or migrates into broader equity vol / systematic flows (Barron’s).
Geopolitical optionality: Iran naval rhetoric adds a two-way risk for crude/real yields; markets may underprice a weekend headline gap given reduced liquidity (Guardian).

market_pricing.dominant_narrative: Fed-regime uncertainty and rates repricing (Warsh nomination) spilling into USD strength and a sharp gold/silver reversal; equities (especially duration/NQ) trade as a function of real-yield sensitivity.
market_pricing.rates_path: Pricing bias appears to be trimming near-term easing expectations (hawkish skew) given the Warsh nomination narrative and recent Fed rhetoric; confirmation needed from actual front-end pricing in the next session (FT).
market_pricing.risk_sentiment: Risk tone is fragile: policy uncertainty + shutdown headlines + China growth softness create a backdrop where negative shocks propagate faster than positive surprises.
market_pricing.gold: Gold is trading less as an inflation hedge and more as a policy/real-rate/positioning instrument: the sharp reversal suggests crowded long positioning was vulnerable once USD strengthened (Barron’s).
market_pricing.equities: Index performance is likely to remain concentrated and narrative-driven (policy/rates + megacap earnings), with downside convexity higher if vol-control/CTA-type flows respond to the metals/FX/rates shock.

risk_register.risk: Fed-chair nomination path creates prolonged regime-uncertainty premium (confirmation timing, Senate optics, perceived independence) -> volatile repricing of real yields/USD and duration equity multiples.
risk_register.timeframe: Days to weeks (headline-driven; elevated into confirmation/communications milestones).

risk_register.risk: Precious-metals deleveraging spills into broader risk via margin/VAR (systematic de-grossing) rather than fundamentals.
risk_register.timeframe: Immediate (next 1–3 sessions), especially if follow-through selling persists.

risk_register.risk: Partial government shutdown extends beyond the weekend and begins to disrupt data releases / agency functions, increasing macro-data uncertainty and policy headline risk.
risk_register.timeframe: This week; focal point Monday House vote (Feb 2).

risk_register.risk: China slowdown signal deepens (PMIs <50) -> global growth scare, cyclicals/commodities down, safety bid in duration; can conflict with any geopolitics-driven oil/inflation impulse.
risk_register.timeframe: This week into next; follow-through risk around subsequent China activity data.

risk_register.risk: Iran escalation headlines over the weekend reprice oil risk premium and revive inflation-risk framing (risk-off + energy up + long-end volatility).

event_warnings: Weekend-to-Monday gap risk: shutdown politics + Iran headlines can hit when liquidity is thin (Guardian).
Feb 2 (Monday) expected House action on funding/DHS extension is a discrete headline catalyst; outcome affects shutdown duration and risk premium (Guardian).
Near-term “rates sensitivity” remains the key transmission mechanism for ES/NQ and gold: any follow-up commentary on Warsh nomination or Fed independence can produce outsized moves (FT, Barron’s).
Watch for follow-through from China PMI shock at the next Asia open; if commodities and global cyclicals fail to stabilize, risk-off can persist into US cash (Reuters).
